Subject files: National Aeronautics and Space Administration

Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 Eva----Astronaut James B. Irwin, lunar module pilot, works at the Lunar Roving vehicle during the first Apollo 15 lunar surface extravehicular activity (EVA-1) at the Headley-Apennie landing site. The shadow of the Lunar Module "Falcon" is in the foreground. This view is looking northeast, with Mount Hadley in the background. This photograph was taken by Astronaut David R. Scott, commander

Verso: Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 Eva----Astronaut James B. Irwin, lunar module pilot, works at the Lunar Roving vehicle during the first Apollo 15 lunar surface extravehicular activity (EVA-1) at the Headley-Apennie landing site. The shadow of the Lunar Module "Falcon" is in the foreground. This view is looking northeast, with Mount Hadley in the background. This photograph was taken by Astronaut David R. Scott, commander

Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 EVA photo-Astronaut David R. Scott, commander, standing on the slope of Hadley Delta, uses a 70 mm camera during Apollo 15 extravehicular activity (EVA) on the lunar surface. He is some 10.5 miles (or 17.5 kilometers) from the base of the Apennine Mountains seen in the background. Scott carries tongs in his left hand. The Lunar Roving Vehicle (LRV) or Rover is in the background. This view is looking east

Verso: Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 EVA photo-Astronaut David R. Scott, commander, standing on the slope of Hadley Delta, uses a 70 mm camera during Apollo 15 extravehicular activity (EVA) on the lunar surface. He is some 10.5 miles (or 17.5 kilometers) from the base of the Apennine Mountains seen in the background. Scott carries tongs in his left hand. The Lunar Roving Vehicle (LRV) or Rover is in the background. This view is looking east

Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 EVA photograph---Astronaut James B. Irwin, lunar module pilot, gives a military salute while standing beside the deployed U.S. flag during the Apollo 15 lunar surface extravehicular activity at eh Hadley-Apennine landing site. The flag was deployed toward the end of EVA-2. The Lunar Module "Falcon" is in the center. On the right is the Lunar Roving Vehicle. This view is looking almost due south. Hadley Delta in the background rises approximately 4,000 meters (about 13, 124 feet) above the plain. The base of the mountain is approximately 5 kilometers (about 3 statute miles) away. This photograph was taken by Astronaut David R. Scott, Apollo 15 commander

Verso: Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 EVA photograph---Astronaut James B. Irwin, lunar module pilot, gives a military salute while standing beside the deployed U.S. flag during the Apollo 15 lunar surface extravehicular activity at eh Hadley-Apennine landing site. The flag was deployed toward the end of EVA-2. The Lunar Module "Falcon" is in the center. On the right is the Lunar Roving Vehicle. This view is looking almost due south. Hadley Delta in the background rises approximately 4,000 meters (about 13, 124 feet) above the plain. The base of the mountain is approximately 5 kilometers (about 3 statute miles) away. This photograph was taken by Astronaut David R. Scott, Apollo 15 commander

Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 EVA photo----Astronaut James B. Irwin, lunar module pilot, walks away from the Lunar Roving Vehicle during the third Apollo 15 lunar surface extravehicular activity (EVA-3) at the Hadley-Apennine landing site. The Rover is parked a short distance from the rim of Hadley Rille. The far wall of the rille is in the distance at the extreme upper left. Irwin is holding the 500m Hasselblad camera in his left hand. This photograph was taken by Astronaut David R. Scott, commander

Verso: Manned Spacecraft Center, Houston, Texas Apollo 15 EVA photo----Astronaut James B. Irwin, lunar module pilot, walks away from the Lunar Roving Vehicle during the third Apollo 15 lunar surface extravehicular activity (EVA-3) at the Hadley-Apennine landing site. The Rover is parked a short distance from the rim of Hadley Rille. The far wall of the rille is in the distance at the extreme upper left. Irwin is holding the 500m Hasselblad camera in his left hand. This photograph was taken by Astronaut David R. Scott, commander

Subject files: Nepal (coronation ceremony of King Mahendra)

Mahendra Bin Bikram, Shah Deva in his coronation crown, Katmandu, Nepal, 1955 [1956?]; LT was the US Ambassador to the coronation. Jewels in crown worth many millions. Feathers of the Greater Bird of Paradise. (Only the king and queen of Nepal can wear them. Many years ago the nations united in forbidding women wearing them because the birds of paradise in New Guinea were almost extinct.)

Verso: Mahendra Bin Bikram, Shah Deva in his coronation crown, Katmandu, Nepal, 1955 [1956?]; LT was the US Ambassador to the coronation. Jewels in crown worth many millions. Many years ago the nations united in forbidding women wearing them because the birds of paradise in New Guinea were almost extinct.)

Subject files: Captain Rex Palmer

Captain Red Palmer Man I flew with in 1917 at Kantara filming the Suez Canal. He had been a test pilot. After the war he became famous in England on the BBC for his program for children. He was known as Uncle Rex. He was the second airman whom I flew The first havin been the South African Major Emmett.........
